awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Multi-scale Modeling and Measurement of Clay Aggregate Behavior
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this research is to advance the understanding of the mechanical behavior of clays as engineering materials.  Clays comprise very fine (< 2 um), electrically charged, chemically active particles whose behavior and assembly are strongly affected by physico-chemical forces operating on individual particles at the smaller (i.e., molecular and interfacial) scales.  Clay minerals of different varieties occur widely in natural geological environments and are generally found in the form of aggregates or clusters whose interactions control the macroscopic engineering properties of clay-rich soils used in the design and construction of infrastructure.  While micromechanics-based experimental and computational research has advanced significantly the understanding of the behavior of sands (particle sizes greater than 75um), the importance of the particulate nature of clays has not been extensively investigated.  This collaborative project aims to develop and validate a new multiscale framework for understanding the macroscopic (i.e., continuum scale) mechanical properties of clays by studying the microscale aggregation of elementary clay particles and the interactions between the resultant clay aggregates. The project will provide the fundamental understanding needed to develop the next generation of constitutive models for mechanical properties of clays that can be used for subsurface engineering, ultimately reducing risks and costs associated with the design of foundations, underground construction and use of geological energy resources (e.g., clay shales, etc.).  The research will impact directly upon the education of future geotechnical engineering and geomechanics students through the creation of online modules related to the small-scale measurement and multiscale modeling of clay behavior. 

The research work comprises a closely-integrated program of multiscale experimentation, atomistic and coarse-grained multiscale simulations for one common clay mineral, illite.  The research involves the following main tasks: 1) modeling and experimental validation of individual clay aggregate behavior under a range of porewater chemistry conditions; 2) development of new modeling techniques and experimental methods for investigating aggregate-aggregate interactions and fabric (i.e., quantitative measurement of particle orientation and of orientation distribution function); and 3) validation of multiscale model predictions through comparison with macroscopic measurements of clay properties.  Experimental measurements will use existing laboratory facilities at the University of Massachusetts Amherst (UMass) as well as the analytical facilities at the Argonne National Laboratory, while numerical simulations at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) will take advantages of NSF eXtreme Science and Engineering Discovery Environment (XSEDE) national supercomputing resources.  By developing a framework for understanding particulate-based clay micromechanics, the research aims to provide an innovative multiscale perspective for explaining the underlying basis of continuum-based clay properties such as cohesion and creep, which have to date only been observed phenomenologically via macroscopic approaches.  The long-term goal is to generalize the methodology to enable bottom-up prediction of mechanical properties for complex natural soils that comprise mixtures of different clay minerals with silt- and sand-sized particles as well as varying porewater chemistry.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to establish a basic multiscale framework for particulate-based behavior and mechanics of clays through integrated experiments and modeling. Specific experimental objectives included microscale measurements of mechanical properties of individual clay aggregates and inter-aggregate interactions and microstructure of clay aggregates. Other computational objectives consisted of bottom-up computational modeling, including molecular and mesoscale simulations, to determine the potential functions for clay aggregates, which were then used to model inter-aggregate interactions. Finally, by systematically validating the numerical simulations for specific clay-water-salt systems, the project acquired the multiscale measurements and modeling results to understand continuum-based clay behavior.

 

Outcomes related to intellectual merits:

The experimental work consisted of clay aggregate preparation and characterization, micro/nano-mechanical testing of individual clay aggregates, and measuring interaggregate interactions. For aggregate microstructure, 2DXRD were employed to characterization orientation distributions of clay particles inside individual aggregates. Illite was selected as the model clay mineral extensively studied in this project, due to its abundance in marine environments and chemical properties intermediate between kaolinite and smectites. For the purpose of comparison, kaolinite and smectite (a Na-montmorillonite) were also studied. Illite aggregates/flocs were prepared under varying salt concentration, pH, and hydrodynamic shearing to further vary the strength of clay aggregates.

An innovative measurement technique, together with a novel 10 mg loading system, was developed to perform compression testing of individual clay aggregates. This system was also equipped with a real-time imaging system to record the entire loading process. This is a unique advancement when compared with conventional macroscale element-based geotechnical testing systems. The developed micromechanical characterization techniques can be easily extended to study other fundamental soil behavior and properties and their underlying microscopic mechanisms, such as attractive forces due to water meniscus (unsaturated), and localized measurements of solid cementation between two particles. A second advancement is the contact mechanics-based analyses of the load-deformation-stress-strain of individual clay aggregates, which led to the determination of elastic modulus and yield strength of individual clay aggregates that experience nonuniform stresses and strains when subject to compression loading. Such an analytical approach was also extended to 2 or 3 aggregate interactions, and could be extended to mesoscale bulk soils consisting of numerous aggregates (investigated by numerical simulations).

Understanding of aggregation mechanisms was achieved by studying particle/aggregate size kinetics of flocculated clay suspensions with varied ionic strength, pH, and hydrodynamic shearing. In general, higher salinity combined with a lower pH can result in larger and stronger aggregates, and higher turbulent flow shear stress can further result in mechanical strength improvement of the aggregates. However, higher hydrodynamic shearing can also reduce the size. The entire compression of an aggregate can be divided into 3 different stages: purely elastic, elasto-plastic, and elastic densification stage featuring rapid load increase with relatively smaller deformation.

The microstructure of aggregates can vary with the clay mineralogy and the environmental factors such as salinity, pH, and hydrodynamic shearing. Basically two different microstructures were observed: homogeneous microstructure with more or less uniform interparticle pores, and hierarchical structure with a macro-aggregate consisting of multiple micro-aggregates and hence double porosities. Under compression loading, aggregates with these two microstructures exhibit contrasting load-deformation curves: the former usually exhibits a relatively smooth, monotonic curve, while the latter is characterized by multiple serrations, which are characteristic of localized slippage or failure. For clay particle orientation, despite some local preferred orientation of clay particles within the flocculi, globally clay particles inside a macro-aggregate do not exhibit preferred orientation. However, under compression loading, especially in the 3rd stage (i.e., elastic densification), highly preferred orientation gradually develops with increasing deformation.

Multiple aggregate interactions result in the merging of two adjacent ones. The interaction forces could be then attraction for two partially joined aggregates. As such, adhesive contacts are considered in the interpretation of aggregate-to-aggregate interactions. The elasticity and yielding of aggregates also vary with particle size, and hence can be best described by Weibull distributions. Moreover, kaolinite aggregates are much stiffer and stronger than the other counterparts made of illite or smectite.

 

Outcomes related to broader impacts:

The project attracted, trained, and mentored students of diverse origins and backgrounds in basic and advanced geotechnical laboratory testing including 1 undergraduate, 1 high school, and 2 graduate students. One high school (trained remotely) woman student helped analyze the statistics of clay aggregates in summer 2020 and was admitted to MIT. Of these 4 students, 2 were women students.

 

Research results and findings have been and will be continuously disseminated via journal publications and conference proceedings so that the impact can reach out to different communities and disciplines worldwide. To date, one conference paper has been published, two journal papers have been submitted for review, and two more journal manuscripts are under preparation. In addition, results have also been disseminated in some local conference presentations and webinars for wider audience, including international students and researchers.

Images (1 of )
  • A micromechanical testing system was developed to apply compression force on individual clay aggregates submerged in water/solution. Load is 10 mg maximum and aggregate size is ~200 microns. The deformation process is recorded by a high-resolution camera.
    Tao Jiang and Guoping ZHang
    Public Domain
    Guoping Zhang
    Individual clay aggregate testing technqiue
  • Highly spherical clay aggregates were prepared by multiple steps, involving initial dispersion, adjustment of solution concentration and acidity (pH), and hydrodynamic shearing force and duration. As a result, clay aggregates can form with varied sizes, stiffness, and strength.
    Tao Jiang
    Public Domain
    Guoping Zhang
    Method of clay aggregate preparation
  • The mechanics of a soft aggregate being compressed between two flat rigid platens is analyzed by Hertz elastic contact theory. As such, the elasticity and yield strength can be determined experimentally.
    Guoping Zhang and Tao Jiang
    Public Domain
    Guoping Zhang
    Contact mechanics for aggregate compression
  • The compression deformation of a soft clay aggregate being compressed between two flat platens can be divided into three stages: purly elastic, elastoplastic, and elastic densification.
    Tao Jiang and Guoping ZHang

    Compression behavior of individual clay aggregates
  • Comparison of different mechanical load-deformation curves for two different clay aggregates: a microaggregate with homogeneous structure and a macroaggregate with heterogeneous structure.
    Tao Jiang

    Distinct response of clay aggregates due to microstructure
